comments.raw_text: If you do a quick search w/ no results, you get a nice hatching pattern and a message saying there are no results. It would be nice to do the same for view | threads | unread, and threads with unread. I know it pains Andrew greatly to invest in the old-style views, but it would help with support when users accidentally switch views. So if it's easy, I'd like to do this...

comments.text:
From an interface perspective, the dreamiest option seems like it would be to integrate "threads with unread" into the quick-filter-bar as a hidden thing that only shows up when active (as triggered by the menu).  This would get you everything for sorta free.  Since we already have "unread", maybe the other option could just divert to that.  (Or even fancier, maybe "unread" could become a combo-button when in threaded mode so you could switch between unread/threads-with-unread.)

The problem is that "threads with unread" is mutually exclusive to the quick filter because it's a specialized view type and it's expressed in a different manner than all the quick filter things (which just generate search terms).

So let's write that off unless you are feeling particularly ambitious.

QuickFilterBarMuxer.reflectFiltererResults is the guy who sets the styling attributes that gets the hatching pattern:
http://mxr.mozilla.org/comm-central/source/mail/base/content/quickFilterBar.js#276

The easiest thing would be to convince that code that dbView.specialViewThreadsWithUnread means that filtering is happening.  It might be appropriate to uplift (some of) the modified code into the FolderDisplayWidget.

The "no results" text only happens when the quick filter bar is active (and therefore presumed visible).  If you changed QuickFilterBarMuxer.onActiveAllMessagesLoaded to fire for your special case as well, you could probably get that code to fire too.  Note that this would increase the set of possible state transitions and so would require additional unit tests unless you are very careful about it.
